description: Introduction to concepts and methods of calculus for students with little or no previous calculus experience. Polynomial and elementary transcendental functions and their applications, derivatives, extremum problems, curve-sketching, approximations; integrals and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
name: INTRODUCTION TO CALCULUS

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to concepts and methods of calculus for students
with little or no previous calculus experience. In particular, this covers polynomial and
elementary transcendental functions and their applications, derivatives, extrema
problems, curve-sketching, approximations; later on, the course touched upon integrals
and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Most students found that this course was interesting, and they thought that it
covered the basic principles of calculus well. However, some students commented that
this course was difficult for someone with no experience in calculus. A majority also felt
that the examples in class “did not always match the questions on the exam.”
The students were very complimentary of Professor Blair’s teaching style. They
felt that he did a good job covering the material, and he was always “available for extra
help.” Some students mentioned that when he went through the in-class problems “stepby-
step,” the lectures were especially productive. A few students felt that he moved too
fast for students without any calculus background, however.
Overall, the students found this course to be “challenging.” It fulfills the formal
reasoning sector.

MATH 103 is an introduction to concepts and methods of calculus for students
with little or no previous calculus experience. Topics include polynomial and elementary
transcendental functions and their applications, derivatives, extremum problems, curve
sketching, approximations; integrals and the fundamental theorem of calculus. MATH
103 satisfies the Formal Reasoning requirement.
Most students did not find lectures helpful; instead, they referred to the textbook,
homework assignments, and outside help to master the material. Many felt that they
needed to have taken calculus in high school to understand what Professor Zhu was
teaching.
Students found Professor Zhu “unable to stimulate the course material,” and many
noted that the language barrier made lectures very difficult to understand. Students felt
that Professor Zhu was generally unresponsive to their questions, unable to explain
course concepts, and unable to communicate effectively with the class.
Ultimately, most students advised against taking Professor Zhu’s class due to the extreme
lack of communication, which made homework and exams very difficult.
